top_comment.text:
Gods, I've been saying this for months -- years, even, since I put the 
pieces together and realized that there's a concerted effort among a 
certain paleoconservative, hyper-capitalist element in our society, in and 
out of government, to sabotage, defund, and discredit the government -- 
primarily the federal government but also the state government -- to such a 
degree as to render the privatization of some or all governmental functions 
more palatable to enough of the American people so that they can, once and 
for all, dissolve most or all of the government that durst regulate 
business in any way, probably only keeping those aspects thereof that they 
can use to exert their will over the "consumers."

This may sound like hyperbole, but these people fit within any reasonable 
definition of "enemy, foreign or domestic" -- in this case, largely 
domestic, although there are foreign corporations that have significant 
shares in propaganda arms within this country that are used to sway people 
to vote against their own interests.  I'm not saying that criticizing 
certain aspects of government or society or promoting certain ideas is 
treasonous, but this kind of wholesale manipulation is not intended to 
increase the quality of life or the efficiency and effectiveness of 
government but rather to artificially render it obsolete.

Now, it may be the case that, in the course of time, a certain form or 
manifestation of government naturally becomes obsolete.  This could be due 
to irreconcilable differences among constituent populations (à la 
Czechoslovakia), or it could be that, sometime down the line, a vast 
majority of the people of said state decide that a hierarchical 
governmental structure is not how they want to go about perpetuating and 
taking care of their society (such as the proposed "Venus Project").

However, intentionally wreaking havoc on such a massive scale by causing 
widespread confusion or spreading so many outright lies in an organized 
manner for the purpose of paralyzing the government and sabotaging the 
people's faith therein is not fundamentally different from waging war on 
the government and thus the Constitution -- the social contract -- that 
enables our system of government and protects our way of life, although it 
can only do that so long as enough people treat it as the supreme law of 
the land that it is.

"Corporate personhood" gives a small number of people within an 
organization the ability to use the resources accumulated by a much larger 
number of people as their own power-base in order to effect changes via a 
for-sale government that naturally suit them and not the people by whose 
authority government governs and without regard for the mandates by which 
representatives, senators, and presidents are sent to Washington, D.C., to 
do the job of governance.  Corporations, however, are greedy and rapacious. 
 This is not a value-judgment, per se, but rather a statement of fact.  In 
the system that we have set up for doing business, corporations *have* to 
be greedy and rapacious, doing literally whatever they can to meet their 
bottom line: the acquisition of money at the cost of nearly anything else. 
 Purposefully taking a financial hit for any reason other than the promise 
of *more* money later is grounds for a lawsuit from one or more 
stock-holders, whose investment is considered "stolen" if the petroleum 
company (for instance) in which they've invested their money decides *not* 
to built a disastrously dangerous pipeline because it will very likely have 
an immensely devastating effect on the environment.  It is possible that 
some corporations may be able to get away with it by stipulating to its 
shareholders that certain environmental and social justice issues may take 
precedence over money, but if that's an option, then most are not willing 
to do that.

This is why corporations shouldn't be running things.  Allowing them to 
contribute virtually limitless funds to candidates and causes, often 
without having to reveal their true nature or the amount of money spent in 
their propaganda, is like making specific accommodation for criminally 
insane people who represent the very worst of human nature to hold 
unelected positions of authority in a community.

We share this home, so to speak, and to a certain degree, We the People 
have a right to set certain limits on the behaviors that we allow from 
ourselves and others who do business here or with us, and while I don't 
favor a violent uprising against these people, like the Koch Brothers, I do 
absolutely favor fighting back politically.  As I see it, there are at 
least two ways of doing this: 1) Not being fooled and doing whatever you 
can to ensure that as many people with whom you have any contact, direct or 
indirect, have a chance of seeing the truth, too, that these corporations 
do not own this country, they do not own our government, and they do not 
own our people; 2) by removing "corporate personhood" and undoing the 
travesty that was the ruling commonly known as "Citizens United."  Wolf-PAC 
-- the political action committee started by Cenk Uygur of TYT to achieve 
the latter goal -- and other similar groups, such as MoveToAmend, could 
only do good for this nation if one or more of them succeeds, and I truly 
hope that one of them does.﻿
top_comment.author: Alaric Holmes

comments.text:
First, that whole thing about 'private money coming with strings' is 
precisely the problem.  A government that is bought and sold will never 
serve the people's needs.

Second, no, big corporations do NOT have a vested interest in maintaining 
private property rights for the majority of the American people -- only for 
themselves and their allies.  Just ask Monsanto about their disturbingly 
successful efforts to sue farmers after Monsanto allowed their "patented" 
seeds to enter the farmer's land, resulting in the stealing of countless 
acres of land.  This, ye of too much faith, is not the support of 
pro-property rights; this is pro-corporate rights, as they see themselves 
as eminently superior to individual humans and smaller businesses.

Nor do they have any interest in the continuity of a stable government. 
 They are feudalists who truly believe, as their actions demonstrate, that 
most, if not all, government functions can and should be privatized.  Just 
look into the TPP; it places mega-corporations above states, which would be 
the end of our democratic republic, and everyone else's for that matter, as 
we know it.

That said, the effort to destroy this country that I described up above is 
being perpetrated by people on "both" sides; ergo, *I despise Obama as much 
as I despise the Koch brothers* and see them both as being responsible, in 
different ways, for achieving the same goal: the running down of the 
federal government in order to make privatization seem more palatable to 
the American people.  So, the "See?  Obama's an evil leftist and worse than 
any corporation"-argument won't work on me because he's largely a "right 
wing" Republican without the religious fundamentalism.  The American people 
were duped

Don't forget, Obamacare (this "socialist" agenda -- which is nothing more 
than a corporate giveaway via a national mandate) largely originated from 
the "right wing" -- i.e., The Heritage Foundation -- and it was largely 
designed to fail.  Obama's people tweaked it a bit, but it's still highly 
problematic.

American corporatism is feudalism, and free-market capitalism is religion 
dressed in economics.  The former is the sanction of the creation of large, 
transnational organizations whose interests are ultimately at 
cross-purposes with the people of the United States and the government 
itself, given that they can be sued by their shareholders if they DON'T 
devastate the environment in order to make a few extra buck, if they DON'T 
ruin people's lives for the sake of a few extra bucks, and so on and so 
forth.  The latter is predicated on "the invisible hand of the free 
market," which is -- in no uncertain terms, according to Adam Smith (who 
coined the term and wrote about the free market) -- the hand of God.  Adam 
Smith *knew* that economics didn't -- and still doesn't -- work in such a 
way that would make "free market" capitalism work, and yet he believed that 
the God would work "His" will through the "free market."

+Traythug Martin First, the current code, whether you agree with it or not, 
is legal. Second, treating the unequal equally is no fairer than treating 
 the equal unequally. Tax deductions and penalties have their place in a 
properly managed market economy by encouraging or discouraging economic 
decisions which are for the public good but which would never occur in a 
pure free market. For a good list of such, you might want to check out the 
classic basic economics  text by Paul Samuelson. It's available on Amazon 
or at your local public library:  
http://smile.amazon.com/Economics-Paul-A-Samuelson/dp/0070579474/ref=smi_www_rcol_go_smi?_encoding=UTF8&*Version*=1&*entries*=0 
That is not to say that there aren't lots of loopholes in the current code 
which are counterproductive or even destructive, but that is the result of 
the corrupting influence of $$$ in politics.  A 12 or any other percentage 
flat tax is neither fair nor productive.

will be a cost.

That being said, I am not against the ACA, in principle, but privatized 
health care is expensive. We should have had the public option to bring 
costs down as ACA does nothing to bend the cost curve.

comments.text:
Those darn poor people.  They should have all their wages garnished so that 
hospitals can collect on the medical bills those people on Medicaid would 
certainly owe without the program.  You're advocating for even worse than 
the status quo before the ACA.  Without change, the uninsured would have 
risen to unimaginable levels.  It was already 60 million.  What do you 
think would have happened if it hit 100 million?  

Yes, hospitals can go after people financially, but a quick brankruptcy and 
the hospital never sees a dime.  Medicare reimbursement rates cover about 
20 million uninsured.  As for the rest, hospitals have to charge more.  In 
turn, insurance companies charge more which leads to more uninsured.  The 
cycle repeats until the whole system crashes and you have massive amount of 
hospitals and health insurance companies crashing and going out of 
businesses.

We were well on our way to this point.  So then, what was your solution to 
the uninsured issue?

comments.text:
+TheLuckySaGe, I would argue that the notion of taken out a few people in 
order to make the world a better place, is itself a harmfully ineffective 
idea, though not because I am a pacifist, as I have been known to enjoy a 
bit of violence here and there...
The harm in this idea is that this would work at all in the sense that our 
current problems would improve, if it weren't for so-and-so.  In human 
history, this might have been true, as demonstrated with the French "free 
head removal service" they offered to certain aristocrats in the past, but 
today, in most developed countries, it is the *system **itself* that is 
corrupt and is the problem.  If anything, our propensity towards 
"forcefully removing" corrupt individuals from the system, has itself 
caused the system to evolve such that it would persist even without a head. 
Our current sociopolitical problems are different, and they cannot be 
solved by using even the best revolutionary techniques of the past.  Our 
problems are globally unsustainable, unstable, and destructive with a 
rapidity that has no natural analogue in the 4.5 billion year history of 
this entire planet. 
The system is the problem, so if anything,
*Fuck** the system*.

comments.author: Jason Baryla

comments.text:
There is so much wrong with that statement. Where to start...

Okay, firstly that's not a valid comparison. It's logically flawed.
Nobody would force a vegan to eat a hamburger, and they wouldn't force 
someone who was morally opposed to it to use birth control.

For your comparison to work, it would have to look like this:
"You wouldn't force a vegan employer to insure their meat eater employees 
for heart disease, even if they thought heart disease was caused by meat 
(it does increase the risks) and the vegan thought the meat eaters deserved 
heart disease"
And actually, I would.

Secondly, what kind of religious zealot nutjob is against BIRTH CONTROL?!

Further, if abortions are legal then yes, I would force an employer to 
fully cover their employees for legal medical procedures that are 
available. You can argue that abortions shouldn't be legal (though you 
shouldn't even if you're against them, but that's another story) but if 
they are and insurers want to provide that cover, then an employer 
shouldn't be making that decision for other people.

You're trying to garner support by obfuscation and confusion. Not 
surprising really, but it's not ethical. If you really think your position 
is more moral, you should be able to express it cleanly without the 
deliberate attempts to muddy the issue.
